div.head: Insurances
div.p: THE undersigned having been appointed agents in China for the above COMPANY, are prepared to accept ASSURANCE at Shanghae. as under

1st. On Buildings of Brick or Stone, covered with Tiles, Slates, Metal, or other Incombustible Material, when such Buildings are isolated from all others, Rate of Premium, 3/4 per cent per Annum. And on their Contents, at the Rate of 1 per cent
Assurances for 6 Months 3/4, and for 3 Months 1/2, of the Annual Rate will be charged.
ASSURANCES, for the present, will be accepted to the extent of £7,000 only on one Risk.
A Building and its Contents taken together form one Risk. Thus the above Sum may be underwritten either on a Building alone, or the Contents alone ; or, part on the Building, and part on the
No ASSURANCE is to be considered in force until the Premium be paid.
Amongst other advantages of the COMPANY, the ASSURED will be entitled to participated in the Profits after Five successive payments.
Parties applying for ASSURANCES will please send in full particulars of the Risk to be taken; any Deviation from which without the Consent of the COMPANY, will vitiate the POLICY.
JARDINE, MATHESON & Co., Agents in Shanghae.

div.head: Insurance
div.p: THE undersigned are prepared to accept risks on behalf of the following Offices to the amounts indicated opposite each and payable in Hongkong, Canton, Calcutta, Bombay, and London.
Canton Insurance Office, Drs. 100,000 Dr. 200,000 Bombay Insurance Society, ,, 40,000 „ 50,000

div.head: Insurance
div.p: R. B. B. H. BLUNDELL, Esq.

THE undersigned having been appointed Agents for the above Company, are prepared to grant Policies against Fire on the usual terms to the extent of £10,000 an any one Building or on Merchandize Stored in any one Building.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: IS hereby given that the Partnership heretofore subsisting between us. the undersigned as General and Commission. Merchants at Shanhae in China, under the firm of THOS. RIPLEY & Co, has this day terminated by effluxion of time, and is accordingly dissolved.
Dated this Thirty-first day of December, One thousand Eight hundred and Fifty.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE Firm of THOS. RIPLEY & Co., having terminated yesterday, I have taken into Partnership Mr. JOSEPH BLAND, (Nephew of Mr. Thos. Ripley), to continue the business as General and Commission Merchants from this date under the firm of SHAW, BLAND & Co.

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE BUSINESS, as Merchant & Agent, heretofore conducted in this place, by Mr. FAZULBHOY. GOOLAMHOOSUN, in his own name, will from this date be continued by him under the designation of our firm

div.head: Notice of Firms
div.p: THE undersigned have formed a PARTNERSHIP, for the practice of MEDICINE and SURGERY, from this date.
GEORGE ROGERS HALL, A.B.; M.D. JOHN IVOR MURRAY, M.D.; M.R.C.S.E. Shanghae, 1st October, 1850.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: The practical instructions for the “ Navigation of the Yang-tsze-keang" published in our
No. 3, of 17 th ultimo, will be reprinted very shortly, in the form of a Pamphlet, price 10 cents each copy.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: THE Community is respectfully informed, that all Communications, Advertisements, and insertions for the following number, should be sent, on or before Thursday in each week, or they will be too late for the same week's issue.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: JOB PRINTING in all its branches, will be executed at our office, on the usual terms, with the greatest attention and despatch.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: LOCAL BUSINESS.—The Bank receives Money in Deposit as follows:—
1. For 3 Months certain, hearing Interest at
3. For 6 Months certain, bearing Interest at 4 per cent per annum.
4. For 1 Year certain, repayable on 3 Months notice, at 6 per cent per annum.
4. In Current Account, withdrawable on demand in Sums of 10 dollars and upwards.
Current Accounts are kept in Spanish Dollars, balanced Half Yearly, bear no Interest, and are subject to the following Commissions, vis :— When the amount turned over during the
Half Year is under 2,000 dollars, a Half-yearly Charge of 5 dollars will he made.
Do. do. do. 25,000 dollars, 1/4 per cent on the amount
The rate of Commission when the amount turned over exceeds 25,000 dollars, will be fixed by special agreement
Inoperative Accounts will be subject to an Annual Charge on the balance at the above rates.
The Bank issues Notes payable on demand, and grants Bank Post Bills at Three Days' sight free of charge.
The Bank grants Loans and Cash Accounts upon various approved Securities, and discounts approved Bills and Promissory Notes not having a longer period than 3 months to run.

EXCHANGE.—The Bank receives Tenders for the purchase of Bills on England and India, and sells its own Drafts on the Union Bank of London at One Day's to Six Months’ sight and on the National Bank of Scotland and Provincial Bank of Ireland at Short sight; also on the Three Presidences of India, and on Ceylon and Singapore, at Three Days’ to Sixty Days’ sight
Information more in detail will be given at the Bank's Offices here, in Canton, and Shanghae.

div.head: PRESENT PRICES OF PROVISIONS SUPPLIED AT THE SHANGHAE MARKET.

div.p: We have just received the Anglo Chinese Calendar for 1851,* it contains as usual a great variety of useful information.
We select the few following Chinese Proverbs:
“ Not to distinguish properly between the beautiful and ugly, is like attaching a dog’s tail to a squirrel's body.
An avaricious man, who can never have enough, is as a serpent wishing to swallow an elephant.
While one misfortune is going to have another coming, is like driving a tiger out of the front door, while a wolf is entering the back.
To ride a fierce dog to catch a lame rabbit (Useless power over a contemptible enemy.
To attack a thousand tigers with ten men; to attempt a difficulty with incommensurate means.)
To cut off a hen’s head with a battle-axe; (unnecessary valor.)
To instigate a villain to do wrong, is like teaching a monkey to climb trees.
A pigeon sneering at a rock;—a mean man despising a prince.
The fish sports in the kettle, but his life will not be long.
Like a sheep dressed in a tiger’s skin is a superficial scholar.
Like a cuckoo in a magpie’s nest, is one who enjoys another’s labor.
Do not pull up your stockings in a melon field, or arrange your hat under a peach tree, lest people think you are stealing.
By a long journey we know a horse’s strength; so length of days shows a man’s heart”
*To be had at Messrs. H. Fogg & Co.’s

div.head: Atmospherical Changes, During the Week ending 9th January, 1851.
div.p: The first part of the last seven days continued fine weather; Monday and Tuesday being damp and disagreeable, followed on Wednesday and to-day by hard frost. The average temperature of the week has been very nearly that of the corresponding week of last year: in 1850 the mercury standing at 38.6°, and during the past week at 39.2°.
TABLE MEAN DAILY READINGS OF BAROMETER, THERMOMETER, ANEMOMETER, and OMBROMETER
